bleichenbacher.description: Return Of Bleichenbacher's Oracle Threat (ROBOT) vulnerability test results:

chaCha20Preference.description: Server take client preferences into account when deciding if to use ChaCha20 suites :

dhUsesKnownPrimes.description: Reuse of known Diffie Hellman primes :
values: Yes, but they are not weak
Yes, WEAK DH primes are used

dhYsReuse.description: DH empheral server value is reused :

drownErrors.note: True if errors occured while running drowntests

ecdhParameterReuse.name: ECHD parameter reuse :
ecdhParameterReuse.note: DHE or ECDHE parameter reuse saves some CPU (more so for ECDHE than for DHE) at the theoretical expense of a weakening of the 'forward secrecy' rule, which is considered not a problem as long as the reused parameters are cached in RAM only and the server implementation does not leak information on the selected DH/ECDH secret key even when faced with invalid values from the client.

fallbackScsv.note: Indicates if the endpoint supports TLS_FALLBACK_SVC to prevent a downgrade attack

values: At least one browser from our simulations negotiated a Forward Secrecy suite.
Forward Secrecy is achieved with modern clients. For example, the server supports ECDHE suites, but not DHE.
All simulated clients achieve FS. In other words, this requires an ECDHE + DHE combination to be supported.
forwardSecrecy.note: This is based on client simulation results

freak.name: FREAK attack
freak.note:
If a host is vulnerable to this attack is support 512-bit key exchange.
See: https://freakattack.com/

hasSct.description: Certificate has the following embedded SCTs :
values: SCT in the stapled OCSP response
hasSct.note: SCTs (Signed Certificate Timestamps) indicate that the CA has submitted the certificate to a Certificate Transparency log server

hpkpRoPolicy.description: REPORT ONLY HTTP Public Key Pinning Policy

httpForwarding.description: Requests to this url get forwarded to :

openSSLLuckyMinus20.description: Outcome of test for CVE-2016-2107 (Lucky Minus 20) :

openSslCcs.description: Outcome of test for CVE-2014-0224 (OpenSSL Ccs vulnerability) :

noSniSuites.description: List of ciphersuites that are offered when we do not send SNI

poodleTls.description: Outcome of test for Poodle over TLS :

protocols.description: This is a list of supported protocols :

rc4WithModern.description: Is RC4 used with modern browsers :

values: Secure client-initiated renegotiation is supported (DoS risk)
Session resumption is not enabled, session IDs are empty
Endpoint returns session IDs, but sessions are not resumed
Server is intollerant to the session ticket extension

sims.note: Unable to determine DH/ECDH amd FS details from API results at this time.

suites.description: List of cipher suites per protocols

staplingRevocationStatus.description: Certificate revocation status obtained via OSCP stapling

staticPkpPolicy.description: Static Private Key Pinning meanse that the hpkpPolicy is statically embedded in the browser (See: https://community.qualys.com/thread/17152-what-is-static-public-key-pinning)

ticketbleed.note: More information on Ticketbleed (CVE-2016-9244) can be found here: https://filippo.io/Ticketbleed/

vulnBeast.name: Beast
vulnBeast.note: Beast is considered to be mitigated client side now. See: https://blog.qualys.com/ssllabs/2013/09/10/is-beast-still-a-threat
